PrimEcoSys: West Gulf Coastal Plain Small Stream and River Forest
West Gulf Coastal Plain Mesic Hardwood Forest

references.B98PET01NCGP: Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.
references.A74MEA01USGP: Means, D. B. 1974. The status of Desmognathus brimleyorum Stejneger and an analysis of the genus Desmognathus (Amphibia: Urodela) in Florida.Bull. Florida State Mus. 18:1-100.
references.B43BIS01SEGP: Bishop, S., 1943. Handbook of Salamanders - Volume III. Comstock Publishing Company Inc., New York. Pages143-147, 232-236.
references.W14IUC99USGP: IUCN. 2014. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1. http://www.iucnredlist.org. Downloaded March 2016.
references.B05MEA01USGP: Means, D.B. 2005. Ambystoma brimleyorum (Stejneger, 1894). Ouachita Dusky Salamander. In Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA. p. 701-703.
references.B95WIL01NCGP: Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.

habitat_description: Confined to the Ouachita Mountains of Arkansas and Oklahoma, the primarily aquatic D. brimleyorum "is found beneath rock, planks, logs, and other debris in damp woods either in the vicinity or within the water of streams and ponds" (Bishop 1943, Wilson 1995). Gravelly and rocky streams appear to be a preference as juveniles can be abundant under these substrates along streamsides and especially seepages or freshets (Means 1974, Petranka 1998). They are found at elevations in the Ouachitas ranging from 120 to 790 meters (Petranka 1998).
